text: Pours brown with a short lived tan head. Aroma is mainly rolling tobacco with some peat. Flavour is much the same with an underlying sweetness. Its a lovely peaty flavour.

I would have thought this would have scored higher... deep ruby beer with a short-lived tan head. Flavour is rich caramel, sweet honey, peat and smoke. Dried fruits and tobacco... smooth and easy drinking. Lovely.

Bottle at The Bottle Lab, Leek. Pours a deep ruby brown colour with a medium tan head. Aroma of caramel, wood, dark fruits, chocolate, some smoke, peat, slight nuts, a little honey and subtle biscuit. Taste of caramel, dark fruits, wood, smoke/peat, some honey, slight chocolate, a little dried fruits, a hint of chilli and subtle biscuit. Medium to full bodied and soft carbonation. A bittersweet, dried fruit, smoky bitterness in the finish. Very complex, smoky but not overpowering and honeyed and fruity sweetness running throughout. So smooth too. Very good.

22nd April 2017Clear deep red - amber beer, good pale tan head. Palate is smooth with reasonable fine carbonation. Soft malts, sweetish, rich honey underneath. For me there is a little too much smoke which jars against the honey sweetness. Light floral sweetness and modest spicy dark fruits. Smooth semi dry finish. Interesting beer but the smoke is at a level that reduced drinkability.

Bottle from Coppers, Newcastle. Hazy dark brown-copper coloured with a thin white head. It has an oak, currant and whisky flavour with vanilla and slight peated notes followed by a smooth dried fruit, honey and whisky grain finish. Excellent!
Reddy brown beige head leather pipe tobacco. Balanced with a sweetness dusty dry finish interesting.

Smoked, dark malts, burnt molasses, honey, dark fruits. Clear, dark brown, medium, creamy, beige head. Medium sweet. More smoked, dark and toasted malts, caramel, biscuit, charred molasses, grain malts, rye, soft carbonation, full bodied, bitter finish. Nice Scottish Ale, quite like the intensity of smokey, dark malts combined with honey. Bottle from Bottle Shop, Bermondsey.
Cask. Dark red ale with a thick tan head. Smells of chocolate and berries. Quite thick in the mouth, giving chocolate, orange, whisky, toffee. Astounding.
330ml bottle. Pours dark reddy brown with a small head. Aroma is woody tobacco and light smoked bacon. Taste has woody honey to start. Woody smoke finish.

On keg at Ushers. 
Appearance - dark brown with an orange edge to it.
Nose - nuts and toffee. 
Taste - tonnes more praline.
Palate - close to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a long dry finish. 
Overall - surely at this strength this should be under Scotch Ale style. Great balance. Very scoopable at 7.8%.

Keg at Craft Clerko, 20/02/17.
Dark chestnut brown with a decent beige head.
Nose is caramel, honey, brown bread, biscuit, dried fruits.
Taste comprises light smoke, toffee, biscuit, cocoa powder, fruit loaf, toasted brown sugar, dates, figs.
Medium + bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Solid for style.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Lively dark red-brown beer, foamy off-white head. Aroma of earthy malt and slightly sour fruit. Flavour has the same qualities, you can taste the honey with some toffee as well. A bit of smokiness going on too.Nice, rich flavour.
Cask at Smithfield Tavern, Manchester. Dark brown shade. Off-white head. Tastes smoky, earthy and malty. Some honey character shining through. Decent stuff.

Bottle. Ruby body with a medium beige head. Lively carbonation. Good lacing. Aroma of honey, smoke and crème brûlée. Flavour of custard, prunes, cigar and Christmas pudding. Medium body with a smooth texture. Soft fizz. I liked this more as it went on. I found that I had to get used to the beer.

Keg at Casc Aberdeen. Pours dark ruby brown with crème coloured head. Aromas of pine trees, honey, breaking toffee and alcohol vapour. Flavours add warming malt and brandy-soaked fruit. lightened by more toffee and clean, cutting hop. A lovely creamy mouthfeel with moderate carbonation. A deliciously smooth ale.
Keg at the Dark brown.. Thin tan lacing... Soft sweet toffee fruit nose.. Juicy sweet fruits.. Big dry honey.. Bitter front.. Long herbal honey... Tiniest smoke

Pours mahogany, with a tan froth which doesnt last. Nose is smoky, peaty, woody, and treacly. Taste is bitter-sweet, with roasted malt, treacle, herbs, some fruit. Palate is long, rich, and oddly juicy. An excellent smoky beer (which kind of reminded me of a dry stout, rather than other wee heavies Ive had).
Keg at the hanging bat. Pours deep ruby, nose is caramel, varnish, berries, taste is rich, fruity, biscuity, light smoke.

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; dark brown pour with a creamy tan head, aroma has some earthy wood action along with some dark berries, taste has sweet toffee, some tobacco smoke, hint of honey, mellow dark fruits, quite full bodied.

Bottle shared at the Bottle Shop - Bermondsey. Cheers! Pours clear reddish brown with a frothy, khaki head. Lots of dried berries in the nose, maybe faint smoke, burnt caramel. Medium sweet flavour with lots of brown bread, fruitcake, faint ash, a little earthy bitterness. Medium to full bodied with fine to average carbonation. Moderately sweet in the finish, with more dried fruits, toasted brown bread, restrained smoke. Fun stuff.

Bottle split at the bottle shop druid Street. A clear copper nut brown coloured pour with loose of beige head. Aroma is semi sweet nutty malts, brown sugars, earthy, hint of maple, raisin bread. Palate is medium sweet, moderate carbonation, sticky, cakey. . Flavour is composed of semi sweet malts, layered malt, nutty toffee, peat smoke, tcp, maple. Good malty drink.

33cl bottle via bottle shop. It pours a murky pale brown copper color with a smallbeige head. Aroma is roasty and woody, lightly peaty and savoury with notes of ashes red currants cocoa and wood. Taste is sweet with notes of caramel
Molasses vanilla and light ashes and wood astringency. Medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall, ok
